justification: The article notes that "assessments of personality …" are among the many areas for which "Likert (1932) scales have a long history of extensive use."
In discussing response formats, the text includes "physical and mental health" in the list of domains that have traditionally employed "Likert (1932) scales."
The same sentence that cites Likert scales also lists "mental health" as one of the constructs commonly assessed with that discrete measure.
The passage specifies that Likert scales are widely used for "beliefs" among other psychological assessments.
"Opinions" are explicitly mentioned in the enumeration of constructs for which Likert scales have been extensively used.
The authors state that adding "a continuous measure like response time … provide[s] richer insights into the cognitive processes underlying responses."
